webTitle: Cooling babies: saving lives – video

fields.standfirst: Brenda Strohm, TOBY children study co-ordinator, meets parents whose son Thomas suffered a lack of oxygen at birth. Cooling – as pioneered by the TOBY Trial, which started in 2002 – lowers the risk of death or severe impairment by 50% for babies who are deprived of oxygen during birth. Reducing these babies' body temperature by 3C to 4C for 72 hours is now recommended by the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence. Now that the TOBY babies are "TOBY Children", they are being followed up again at school age to assess their progress, in a continued collaboration between Oxford University and Imperial College London, with further funding from the Medical Research Council
fields.headline: Cooling babies: saving lives – video
fields.trailText: Cooling babies who are deprived of oxygen during birth lowers the risk of death or severe impairment by 50%

webTitle: The Lusitania disaster - pictures from the past

fields.standfirst: A photographic highlight selected by the picture desk. On 7 June 1906, the first rivet on the keel plates of the British ocean liner RMS Lusitania was laid at the John Brown Shipyard in Glasgow.  At the time of her maiden voyage in September 1907, she was the world's largest ship.  In August 1914, the Lusitania was requisitioned by the Admiralty and, nine months later, she was torpedoed by a German U-Boat eleven miles off the southern coast of Ireland.  The sinking provoked widespread condemnation of German brutality and contributed to America's entry into the war
fields.headline: The Lusitania disaster - pictures from the past
fields.trailText: A photographic highlight selected by the picture desk. On 7 June 1906, the first rivet on the keel plates of the British ocean liner RMS Lusitania was laid at the John Brown Shipyard in Glasgow. At the time of her maiden voyage in September 1907, she was the world's largest ship. In August 1914, the Lusitania was requisitioned by the Admiralty and, nine months later, she was torpedoed by a German U-Boat eleven miles off the southern coast of Ireland. The sinking provoked widespread condemnation of German brutality and contributed to America's entry into the war

Jo Shapcott teaches on the MA in creative writing at Royal Holloway College, University of London and is also visiting professor in poetry at the University of Newcastle and the University of the Arts, London. She is currently president of The Poetry Society.

Her poetry collections, including Elecroplating the Baby, Phrase Book and My Life Asleep have won numerous awards including the Commonwealth poetry prize for best first collection, and the Forward poetry prize for best collection. webTitle: Detroit struggles with tar sands refinery – in pictures

fields.standfirst:
One day in November, mysterious black piles appeared on the banks of the Detroit River, not far from the Motor City's downtown and right next to the Ambassador Bridge, the busiest international crossing in North America. These huge stockpiles of petroleum coke, the byproduct of refining tar sands oil at the Marathon refinery in south-west Detroit, are owned by Koch Carbon, run by businessmen Charles and David Koch.

This series of photographs takes a closer look at the people the petroleum coke piles are affecting, the areas around the stockpiles and where it is being produced
fields.headline: Detroit struggles with tar sands refinery – in pictures
fields.trailText: One day in November, mysterious black piles appeared on the banks of the Detroit River: petroleum coke, the byproduct of refining tar sands oil at a nearby refinery run by the Koch brothers
